titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Mr Victor de Tracy paid me a visit this morning, and thanked me for the steps I had taken in his behalf.— He is very anxious to obtain the permission to go to France upon parole, but that is now impossible. He is much out of health, and has a complaint in his eyes, which he says the physicians are apprehensive is a gutta serena. It will make him henceforth incapable of performing any military service— He appears to be affected in Spirits as much as in Health. He gave me some particulars concerning the French Prisoners in this Country and their treatment, which differs much in the different Governments. He says that of all the prisoners made in the year 1812. there are not 25000 now remaining alive— The treatment of them is the worst in the Government of Novegorod— I did not go out this day, after the morning walk with Charles— Count Maistre sent me Petau’s Rationarium Temporum; but it does not contain the History of the reformations of the Calendar.

2. Called at the apartments of Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard to see them, but they were abroad. Visited Mr de Tracy at his lodgings at Demuth’s Hotel— Messrs: Gallatin, Bayard, de Tracy, Harris, Barthe, Clapier, Montreal, Milligan, James Gallatin, Lewis, Roberts and Rogers dined with us— Mr Raimbert sent an excuse— Mr Todd went yesterday to Cronstadt and Mr Dallas sent word he had a previous engagement.— The company did not stay late in the Evening. Mr de Tracy has been a traveller over the greatest part of Europe, and before he came to Russia was serving in Spain. He gave me characters of the principal French Generals, and many interesting anecdotes of the Wars. He spoke of Moreau’s conduct with contempt, and indignation; but he said it must have given the highest gratification to the Emperor Napoleon, as justifying all his rigour against him. He ascribed Moreau’s follies and misfortunes to the ascendency of his wife over him, and has a very indifferent opinion of the Lady; and a still worse one of her mother.

3. I read Prayers for the 16th: Sunday after Trinity, and took my walk in the Summer Gardens before dinner. As my study of Chronology is only subsidiary to another purpose, I took this day the first Volume of the Parallele des Religions and consumed several hours in running over the Accounts of the Religion of the Hindus— Then Goguet— Then Count John Potocki, whose book I just begin to understand— He seems to me not so lucid in his method as he is ingenious in his principles. Lenglet Dufresnoy with whom I began languishes; and the logarithms are for the present abandoned. I should pursue this subject with as much pleasure, as ardour and perseverance, did I not find the aid both of my eyes and fingers deserting me more and more from day to day.

4. Mr Wainwright came, and informed me that he intended to go about this day week for England, and offered to take letters for me— Captain Jones was here. He came up from Cronstadt yesterday; and is preparing to go with the Ship to Gothenburg. Mr Gallatin came and passed the Evening with us at Cards— The sudden and violent change of the weather has given us Colds— We have just now put in our double windows— Charles shed his second front lower tooth.— I took up Count John Potocki again— His system brings him again to the same result as that of Lenglet Dufresnoy— That is to the Chronology of the Samaritan Bible. He professes however only to settle it with certainty up to the Birth of Isaac.

5. Walked again with Charles to School, but he has taken a severe Cold, and the Season has come in which I must renounce the practice of taking him on foot— Captain Jones dined with us, and sat after dinner so that I did not read— I am suffering with rhumatism and a Cold— Count John Potocki, Petau, Lenglet Du Fresnoy and Goguet yet engage my time and attention— I read the Article Marsham in the Biographia Britannica; and so much of Sir Isaac Newton’s Article, as relates to his Chronology— It was not published untill after his Death— But an abstract from it had been fraudulently published by an Italian pretended friend to whom he had communicated it.— Without an opportunity to see and consult these Books, and Usher, I cannot be master of my Subject— Many others are equally necessary and equally inaccessible. It is impossible to pursue researches of any kind properly without a large Library.

6. Rose this morning soon after four O’Clock—but it was the effect of a restless Night and drooping health. Charles’s cold was so troublesome that we kept him this day at home— I took only a short walk before dinner— Read some chapters in Goguet, and wrote a double task— Mr de Tracy spent the Evening with us.

7. I took Charles to school again, although he has not entirely recovered from his Cold. Mrs Adams was very unwell the whole day, and in the Evening confined to her bed; severely ill. I continue myself so unwell that I find no resource but in study— This has a charm which gives delight even to hours of pain— I range between Goguet, Schubert, Lenglet and Petau; and write a little, every day. Mr Lewis, Mr Barthe and Mr Clapier, spent two hours of the Evening with us.

8. Mrs Adams though not so ill as yesterday was quite indisposed all this day, and did not dine with us. I had visits from Mr Montréal, and from Mr Hurd with Captain Joseph Brown, who came for a Passport to go to America. I accordingly gave him one. As I proceed in my enquiries I find occasion to question very seriously the accuracy of Schubert’s History of Astronomy— He is too loose and general in his reference to authorities from antient writers— He recognizes the authenticity of fables the falsehood of which appears to me demonstrated in Goguet. He leaves to be implied an assent to some of the ridiculous pretensions to antiquity of the Eastern Nations, which seem to me to vanish more and more in proportion to the extent of enquiry into them— Voltaire’s buffoonery upon the subject is contemptible— But Schubert’s gravity is more equivocal. Goguet has so demolished the 1903 years of Chaldean Observations prior to Alexander, that I can hardly see how they can be maintained in Argument— Voltaire, to be sure speaks of them as certain; but that was to discredit the Bible Chronology— Count John Potocki also recognizes them, though he professes to respect the Scripture Chronology— But he pleads for the Septuagint readings, and places the deluge about 4000 years before Christ. For my own part the further I advance in the examination of Evidence on this question the less reason I perceive for questioning the Bible Chronology; though I still incline to prefer the Septuagint and Samaritan numbers.

9. Mr Appleton was here this morning, and informed me that he intended to go for Gothenburg about the last of next week; and from thence directly to America— He offered to take letters for me. Mr Treadwell came and requested to have the term of his Passport prolonged— He is going also next week, to Vienna— Mr Wainwright called to say that his departure for England was postponed untill the end of the next week— Mr Montreal paid me likewise a visit— On taking Charles to school this morning I stopp’d and engaged with Mr Fishwick to place him there at full board and lodging, from the end of the Quarter now running, untill Christmas. Mr Fishwick spoke very well of his proficiency; said he had no complaints of him now, and that he learnt so well, it was a pleasure to teach him.— Count Maistre paid us a long Evening visit.—

10. Read prayers for the 17th: Sunday after Trinity. Received a note from Count Romanzoff asking me to call upon him at half past twelve O’Clock, at Noon, which I did— He said he had received yesterday a number of letters from the Emperor, and among the rest some concerning our affairs— In one of them he was ordered to receive from us, and forward to the Emperor our Credential Letter, as he the Count
had suggested, so that we might be completely recognized, and the mission fully received as a foreign Legation at this Court— That he had written to us to ask for the Credential Letter, and he left it entirely at our option, to enclose it under a cover to him; or to deliver it to him in person; if we preferred the latter mode we should only have to mention it in a Note, as he should in that case receive us formally in his apartments of Ceremony— That with regard to our being presented to the Empresses, we need give ourselves no trouble— He would consider the application as made, and would take the directions of the Empresses as to the time. That the reigning Empress would probably give us our Audience next Sunday; unless in the interval there should be a Te Deum— In that case he would endeavour to procure us the Audience prior to it, that my Colleagues might have the opportunity to attend it—and he requested me to ask Mr Harris to send him the names of the persons attached to the Legation who wished to be presented to the Empresses. He observed that he had addressed the letter in which he asked us for our credential letter, generally to the Envoys Extraordinary and Ministers Plenipotentiary of the United States, without naming us, because he had not known which of us to name first— That in the Credential he observed I was first named; and that Mr Gallatin’s name was first in the Full-power to treat with England— I told him that it had resulted from a delicacy of attention in the President towards me.— That in the power to treat with England Mr Gallatin’s name was first; to which I could have no possible objection. He having held many years an office of higher rank than any one in which I had been placed— But the President had perhaps thought as I had already been here sometime, it would be in some sort displacing me, to give precedence to another Plenipotentiary before me at the Emperor’s Court, and in the Credential letter had therefore put my name first. It was however a point on which I had no feeling to gratify, and I should be obliged to him if he would always consider Mr Gallatin as the first of the three Plenipotentiaries— He asked me if he should send his communications to the mission, to Mr Harris as the Secretary of the Mission, or continue to send them to me— I said either way, or to the other Plenipotentiaries— They would always be received with equal pleasure, to whomsoever they might come— But he might observe from this expedient that little punctilios of precedence were apt to arise in Republics as well as under other forms of Government. He said that the thought that Republics might naturally be liable to such questions more than other Governments; which remark was very just— Because in other Governments such questions for the most part are settled— In Republics they are always open.— The Count asked me, if I would take the letter myself which I did.— He also shewed me one of the Emperor’s letters to him— It was a note of four lines in the Emperor’s own hand-writing without direction or signature, dated Töplitz 8 September (O.S.) Its purport was thus— “J’approuve complettement Monsieur le Comte, vôtre lettre au Comte de Lieven sur les Affaires d’Amerique; et je vous prie de pour suivre cette affaire de même— Tout a Vous.” This was the whole letter, and the first and last words precisely as I give them; of the others I only recollect the substance. He said that in another of the Letters the Emperor had directed him to apologize to us for the delay of his Answer; which was owing solely to his having been constantly on horseback, and in presence of the Enemy, for several weeks.— He had also sent him orders to furnish Baron Blome with a ship to go home in, and to take with him the effects belonging to the legation—the Count gave me the two collections of the intercepted letters from the french army, taken with the army.— Mails of 12 and 16 September— One of these letters he told me was from the Duke de Vicence and one from the Prince de Neufchatel. The Courier who brought these dispatches left Töplitz 25 September N.S. the Emperor’s letter to the Empress mother was of the day before— The Emperor expected immediately afterwards the arrival of General Bennigsen with his army to join them; and then the main army was to march forward. The Emperor expected great Events from day to day. Napoleon had attempted several times, and on various quarters to penetrate into Bohemia, but had every where been repulsed— Mr Alopeus had written to him the Count, that Napoleon’s marches and countermarches and the extraordinary circumspection of his present movements had considerably affected his military reputation— But the Count added, that he did not join in that opinion— He thought his circumspection a new proof of his ability.— For my part I believe the man is abandoned of God, and that Heaven is breaking one of the instruments of his wrath. The only prayer I dare to form is that by his ruin, still more terrible scourges may not be substituted in his place.— I took the Count’s letter immediately to Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard— We all concurred in the opinion that we should ask an Audience of the Count, and deliver to him the Credential letter in form.— Mr Bayard said this was something; but he had much rather have received the answer from England— He thought our Audience of Introduction to the Empresses, might at the same time be an Audience to take leave— I wrote the Note to Count Romanzoff asking him to appoint a time for us to deliver the Credential
credential to him; and I sent it in the Evening to Mr Gallatin; to be copied, if approved by him, and sent to-morrow morning to the Count by Mr Harris— I also paid a long visit to Count Maistre, and took back to him Paley’s Evidences, and natural Theology which he had lent me— I had a long and interesting conversation with him, in which I put him to sleep only once— He was lamenting the ruin and desolation of Saxony— I said I thought Prussia must also deserve some share of commiseration; but he said the cases were entirely indifferent— People that were ruined in a good cause did not feel it at-all like those who were ruined in a bad one.— Mr Bayard, Mr Todd and Dr Lawton spent the Evening with us.

11. I received this morning from Count Romanzoff, an answer to my note, appointing to-morrow at Noon to receive our Credential letter— I took it to Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard— I thence went and called upon Mr Meyer, but he was not at home— I then went to Mr Harris, and shewed him the manner in which dispatches should be copied, according to the Instructions from the Secretary of State— Mr Barthe called upon me to tell me that he and Mr Clapier would be ready to go next Thursday, and wished to obtain their Courier’s Passport for that time— They go by water from Cronstadt to Sweden— I wrote to Count Romanzoff for the Passport— Mr Gallatin mentioned to me that Mr Dallas was going to leave them— He was going to England— Had concluded to go next Friday; and wished for a Courier’s Passport— I mentioned the necessity of his being advertised in the Papers; the rule I had always observed on this subject and its motives.— Mr Montreal paid me a morning visit— He told me that Colonel Rapatel had arrived, with the body of General Moreau, which is to be buried from the Catholic Church— Rapatel has told all the Circumstances of Moreau’s death— He was reconnoitreing with the Emperor before Dresden, 27 August— The fourth Cannon-Ball that was fired struck him; killed his horse; crushed both his legs; killed another horse, under an officer standing by him, and passed under the Emperor Alexander’s horse’s head— Moreau fell with his horse—instantly raised himself upon his two hands, and said “je suis perdu”— Rapatel had sprung from his horse, and raised Moreau, by holding him up under the arms; at the same time endeavouring to cheer and comfort him with hopes— After a few minutes he said “que ce Coquin de Bonaparte est heureux.”!— He was placed upon a litter, and soon after asked Rapatel to feel into his side pocket where he would find a flint and steel and some Sigarrs— He struck the fire and lighted a Sigarr; from which time he never manifested a sign of complaint— The legs were amputated the same day— He was removed on the litter to Toplitz, where he died the 2d: of September.— Mr Montreal says also that a Treaty of subsidy has been signed at the Emperor’s Head Quarters with England; for two Millions Sterling—one in specie and one in warlike Stores— Six Millions of Rubles have already been drawn for.— Mr Todd and Dr Lawton dined with us— The Doctor was taken suddenly very unwell, while we were at dinner and was obliged to leave the Table— He returned to it for a few minutes, but continued so unwell that he left it a second time, and went away. Mr Lewis spent the Evening with us.

12. The Cold and rainy and dark Season is seriously setting in, and afflicts us all with Colds and Rhumatisms— It was midnight last Night when I retired, and I was up at 5 this morning, by Candle-light— The second time this Season. I now take Charles to school, almost every morning in the Carriage. Mr Meyer called on me, and I requested him to take my Bills upon Amsterdm. the Exchange has already risen a Stuiver, and I apprehend this subsidy will raise it so much more, that unless I draw now I may be forced to draw at a moment when the loss may be three times as heavy.— I have also got into a difficulty about Mr Wolcott’s Commission to procure him some seeds of plants. He sent me a Bill for £100. Sterling, supposing it would be more than sufficient to pay for his whole list, and all the charges— I gave the list to Mr Meyer requesting him to inform me, where they could be procured— But he found they were not to be had here, and wrote his friends at Moscow; they immediately procured them almost all, and are sending them on here by land.— But there was one Article which cost more than double the amount of the Bill, which Mr Wolcott thought would pay for the whole— He had written for 25 lbs of Cauliflower seed— But it costs 150 Rubles a pound. Mr Meyer’s friends purchased only eighteen pounds, and they come to 2700 Rubles— The other Articles will not much exceed Mr Wolcott’s expectations— But as this would run up far beyond his calculation, I desired Mr Meyer to send back the Cauliflower, reserving only two or three pounds, and to make an allowance to the seller, if necessary for taking it back— I shall be not a little perplexed how to send the other articles unless they should arrive before Captain Jones sails. At Noon according to appointment I called upon Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard, and we went together to
Count Romanzoff’s— I delivered to him our Credential letter to the Emperor; and he repeated to us almost every thing that he had said to me on Sunday. He said he had already spoken to the Empress, to request that if there should be a Te Deum, we might be presented to her before it, that Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard may have the opportunity to attend it; and he should rejoyce in having so happy an occasion for our presentation— I consider it as infallible— He told us that he had written this day to Mr Narishkin the Grand-Master of the Ceremonies, to take the orders of the Empresses on the subject— The reigning Empress went yesterday to visit the Empress mother at Gatschina where she would stay untill to-morrow Night. the Empress Mother would stay untill the 14/26. her birth day at Gatschina— That day she would come to Pavlofsk where the reigning Empress and the Imperial family would dine with her— She would stay there untill the 17/29 when she would come to the City for the Winter. Mr Bayard asked the Count whether Lord Walpole was coming here— He said the letters from Vienna mentioned that Lord Walpole was there, and coming here— As the Emperor Francis, and Count Metternich, his Minister of foreign Affairs were both absent from Vienna, he did not know why Lord Walpole had chosen precisely that moment to go there, unless it was, that having to arrange the matter of a subsidy, his business might be with the Minister of the finances at Vienna— Lord Aberdeen had presented his Credentials to the Emperor of Austria, as British Ambassador. He had been commissioned and dispatched from England before the end of the Armistice, upon the confidential communications of Russia to the British Government; of the dispositions of Austria to change her system. And he had arrived at the head-quarters, and found all prepared for his reception, as had been anticipated. It was now said upon very good authority that the king of Bavaria, had detached himself from his alliance with France, and made an arrangement with Austria— He had no official account of this himself; but it was reported on authority which deserved full credit— Mr Gallatin asked whether in any arrangement which might be negotiated between Austria and Bavaria, the Tyrol would not come in for something— The Count answered, that the Tyrol was in a state of insurrection. That Count Stackelberg had written him so from Vienna, and that they had refused a passage to the French troops.— He then asked us if we had ever seen any Tyrolians— Mr Gallatin said he had once seen one— The Count said he had seen numbers of them on his Mission in Germany, and afterwards by the Emperor’s orders he had been in relations with their deputies— They were a very singular people—a loyal, brave, honourable people; but their coquetterie consisted in opposition— He had asked them what Sovereign they themselves would prefer—they said, the house of Austria—but upon Condition they should be better treated than they had been— They were willing to try the house of Austria again; and if upon trial they should not be satisfied they would look out elsewhere.— From the Count’s I went to call upon Mr Narishkin the Grand-Master of the Ceremonies, but he was not at home— Mr Bayard and Coll. Milligan spent the Evening with us.

13. Mr Meyer sent me this morning the bills upon Amsterdam for which I had spoken to him— With a minute that the other affair that I had mentioned could not be effected— Afterwards in the course of the day they sent me a second Note, that it could; though not without a loss of about five per Cent— I conclude to try it even at that— There is such hazard in the management of funds here, and such excessive fluctuations, which I am altogether unable to foresee, that my care of property is as unsuccessful as that of my health— For more than two years I have been making continual and heavy losses, and every precaution I have taken has been baffled. My utmost success has been to moderate the loss— The effect that it ought to have upon my mind would be a conviction of my own shallowness of judgment or insufficiency of foresight— But this is so mortifying a lesson that we are all unwilling to learn it— I received from Count Romanzoff the Passport for Mr Barthe, with two packets for Mr Daschkoff. Received also a notification from the military Governor of the City, Wiasmitinoff, that the funeral of General Moreau, would be to-morrow Morning at ten O’Clock, from the Catholic Church. Mr Treadwell called upon me to mention that he should leave the City for Vienna to-morrow Morning— As he is going by the way of Königsberg I gave him a letter for Messrs: Schwink and Koch— These little incidents together with the usual concerns of the family on the commencement of the Russian Month wasted the day so that I scarcely wrote any-thing, except to keep my Journal from running in arrear— I was obliged to suspend my Chronological enquiries; but read in the Evening a few pages of Goguet— Finished his first Volume, with the exception of the Dissertations.

14. Rose before 5. and read and wrote about two hours by Candle-light. At ten O’Clock I went with Mr Smith to the Roman Catholic Church, and attended the funeral ceremonies for the interment of General Moreau. His body had been transported to this
City for that purpose by the Emperor’s orders; and was accompanied by Coll: Rapatel, who had been the General’s Aid de Camp, and whom the Emperor has now appointed one of his Aids.— The Church service was performed by the Archbishop of Mohileff, the Roman Catholic Metropolitan of the Empire— The Music was the same that had been composed for the funeral of the late King of Poland. The singing was very good.— The Sermon was preached in French, by father Rosavel, Professor of Philosophy at the Jesuit’s College. His text was from the Wisdom of Solomon, Ch. 9. v. 13. “For what man is he that can know the Counsel of God? or who can think what the will of the Lord is?” It was delivered from Memory—short—not exceeding fifteen Minutes— Remarkable for moderation in the Sentiments, and without one word of invective against Bonaparte, or even of allusion to him— The biographical sketch of Moreau’s history was such as might be collected from the Gazettes— His Military exploits sufficiently and not too much detailed— His famous Retreat particularly dwelt upon— His refusal to execute the decrees of the Convention against the Emigrants, and for giving no Quarter to the English and Hanoverians, justly alledged as instances of the humanity and magnanimity of his character— His equivocal transactions with Pichegru, at two different periods, and his accusation of Pichegru at one of them slurr’d over as points too thorny to be discussed.—His trial was only mentioned to say that it cost him the greatest part of his fortune— The Panegyric of the Emperor Alexander was well interwoven with that of the General, and his medal for the year 1812 adduced as a proof of his modesty and Piety— The style of the discourse was altogether temperate, with scarcely one oratorical movement, excepting an Apostrophe to the inhabitants of Augsburg, which was not very well placed— In truth the whole Ceremony was languid— Excepting Coll: Rapatel, there was not perhaps a real mourner in the Church.— He appeared to be much affected; and lamented to me that the Ball had not struck him instead of his General.— The Ministers and Generals of the Country were there; but none of the foreign Ministers excepting Count Maistre—the Chevalier Bardaxi was said to be ill.— The Catafalque was elegant, but plain; without ornaments or trophies. The Church was partly hung in black— The body was deposited in a vault at the right hand of the central aisle of the Church— There were troops drawn up in front of the Church, who fired several vollies of musketry at the moment of interment— The whole Ceremony was about three hours long. It had begun when we arrived; about a quarter past ten— After we returned home Mr Barthe and Mr Clapier called upon me for their Passport— I gave it to them with the packets for Mr Daschkoff— Mr Barthe will call again for mine, to-morrow Morning.— Mr Milligan came this Evening from Mr Gallatin with the draft of a dispatch to the Secretary of State which I signed, together with a triplicate of the letter N. 1.— I also wrote a note to Count Romanzoff asking a Passport for Mr Dallas— Miss Bode was here to visit the Ladies, with news of the taking of Dresden by the allies.

15. Rose again before five—“empor aus schwëren träumen,” And was engaged the whole day in writing letters to send by Mr Dallas. Mr Barthe called and took my letters; he was going immediately down to Cronstadt. Mr de Krabbe, the Secretary to the late Danish Legation came to take leave— They have a Russian Sloop of War to take the whole Legation home, and expect to sail about the middle of next week. Mr Krabbe offered to take any letters or packets for Copenhagen— Miss Bode dined and spent the Evening here. I received a Notification from Count Romanzoff, that the Empress had fixed on Sunday next, at two O’Clock for the American Envoys to be presented to her— Received also Cards to dine with the Count on Sunday.— My occupations for several days have necessarily suspended my reading and writing on antient Chronology, and a drowsy rhumatism disqualifies me from all employment after dinner.

16. Walked with Charles to school; which I can now very seldom do— On my return, I called at the lodgings of Mr Gallatin, and Mr Bayard, but they had not risen— I left the Notification that we are to be presented to the Empress to-morrow— Soon after breakfast a Messenger from the Grand Master of Ceremonies came, and brought me a list of the persons to whom visits are to be paid after the presentation— He said that none of them were to be paid in person, excepting to the Chancellor; but that it was usual before the presentation to visit the Grand Master of Ceremonies; who would be home at 11 O’Clock to-morrow Morning.— Shortly after, I received a Notification from Count Romanzoff, that the Gentlemen attached to the Legation would be presented to the Empress to-morrow, immediately after the Ministers; and also a Passport for Mr Dallas— I took these papers to the lodgings of my Colleagues— I found that Mr Dallas had postponed his departure untill Monday, in order to be included in the presentations to-morrow; and had consequently received an invitation to the Count’s dinner— Mr and Mrs Smith also afterwards received Cards.— We had Evening visits from Mr Todd, Mr Lewis and Mr Slade— Mrs: Adams and Mrs: Smith paid visits to Countess Litta, and two others— Countess Litta informed her that there would be no necessity for her, to be presented again to the Empress.

17. Read prayers for the 18th: Sunday after Trinity, and part of two letters of father Joly; one on the Music of the Hebrews, and the other on the Temples. At eleven of the Morning I called upon Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard, and went with them to visit the Grand Master of the Ceremonies Narishkin— We found with him Mr Swistounoff, the Chamberlain who was to present us to the Empress.— After a short visit we returned home; and at a quarter before two I called upon the Gentlemen again, and we all proceeded, together with Mr Harris the Secretary to the Legation, and Messieurs Dallas, Milligan, Todd, and James Gallatin, as attached to the Mission, to the Palace. We found a Court footman, at the Street door of the Palace, a fourier at the door at the top of the Stair-case—Two Aids of the Department of the Ceremonies in the first Hall, who escorted us to the second where we found Mr Swistounoff— The Grand Master of the Ceremonies, and the Grand-Chamberlain received us at the Antichamber before the Empress’s Apartment.— Mr Gallatin, Mr: Bayard and myself were introduced to the Empress together, Mr Swistounoff introduced us to the Apartment, but remained standing at the entrance door, during our Audience. The Empress stood precisely on the spot where she gave me the first Audience four years ago.— Countess Litta stood behind her; and as at that time no other person was present. The Empress was courteous as usual—spoke of the Climate, and the voyage of my Colleagues, and the length of time they had been here, and their visits to the Curiosities of the City, and of the vicinity.— The Audience was over in five Minutes. We kissed her Majesty’s hand, and retired— After we came out the Gentlemen attached to the Mission were all introduced together by the Grand-Chamberlain— We went and made visits in person, leaving Cards, at Count Romanzoff’s; the Grand Chamberlain Narishkin’s, Countess Litta’s, and the Minister of Finance, Gourieff’s— All the other visits will be paid by Cards. At 4 O’Clock we all went to dinner at Count Romanzoff’s— Madame Bardaxi-Azara was there; and the Duchess de Serra-Capriola—The Betancourt family—Countess Colombi and Miss Frederica Bode—The Corps Diplomatique; Mr Bayley the British Consul, and several English Travellers— I sat at table between Madame de Betancourt and Madame Colombi— Counts Markoff, Samoiloff and Litta, were of the Company— General Betancourt shewed me the Box, with the Emperor’s picture, set round with Diamonds, sent him by the Emperor, with a very gracious letter, on the finishing of his Bridge at Kammenoi-ostroff. Mr Bardaxi introduced me to his Lady.— We came home about 7, and I made a short Evening.— Mr Wainwright had called on me this morning, and goes for England to-morrow. I gave him two packets from the house of Raimbert, for America, that they had just sent me. In the Evening I received a large packet from Count Romanzoff, for Count Lieven the Russian Ambassador at London, to be sent by Mr Dallas.

18. I called this morning at the lodgings of Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard, and left the packet for Count Lieven, to be taken by Mr Dallas— None of them were up— By the mail from Sweden I received packets from Mr Speyer, from Mr Fosdick, and from Mr Hall at Gothenburg—they contained dispatches and letters from America, arrived by two Swedish vessels arrived at Gothenburg, one from Boston, and the other from New-Haven— The dispatches were only the original and duplicate of the Secretary of States letter to the joint Mission, of 23. June. The letters were from my family and friends at Quincy and Boston; but none later than 19. July— There was a packet for Mr Gallatin, containing family letters and newspapers, but not of a later date— But Mr Speyer enclosed to me part of a New-York newspaper of 19. August, and his letter to me mentions that the Senate of the United States had negatived the appointment of Mr Gallatin to the Extraordinary Mission, and confirmed the two other Nominations: After dinner I went to the lodgings of my Colleagues, and took with me the dispatches for the mission and the packet, for Mr Gallatin— I found they had not risen from table— Mr Lewis was there, and I found had received a letter from Gothenburg— Soon after I came, he went out with Mr Bayard to his chamber— Mr Harris came in shortly after— He had received no letters, but Mr Milligan, soon after took him out of the Room, to his chamber.— I was left some time alone with Mr Gallatin who appeared uneasy and under some agitation— Mr Lewis’s letter had mentioned that the nomination of Mr Russell as Minister to Sweden had been negatived by the Senate— Mr Gallatin, expressed an apprehension that the whole Mission Extraordinary had been also negatived; for which he said there were the same motives as for rejecting the appointment of Mr Russell— He asked me if I had no other letter from Mr Fosdick, than the two addressed to the Mission, which I had delivered to him— I had no other, and I thought it would scarcely be consistent with delicacy to tell him what Mr Speyer had written me— I therefore came home to avoid being further pressed with questions, which might
have made it necessary for me to tell him, what he ought to hear from any other person sooner than from me.— While I was out the Chevalier Bardaxi and his Lady paid us a visit, and were received by Mrs: Adams—and after I came home, Mr de Tracy came and spent with us the remainder of the Evening— Mr Dallas went this day for England— My letters from my family brought me distressing accounts of the health of my dear Sister, and of the alarm and affliction of my Mother in consequence of it.

19. Mr Lewis called upon me this Morning, and read to me a letter which he received yesterday from Mr Gair, at Gothenburg. It contained with some other information from America the statement that the nomination of Mr Gallatin to the Russian Mission, had been negatived in U.S. Senate by a majority of one vote— Genl: S. Smith’s—17 and 16— The other two it says were confirmed 27 and 6. and 33 (for 29?) and 4. but which had the 6 and which the 4 opposing votes he did not know— Mr Bayard and Mr Harris came while Mr Lewis was here. He then left me— He had informed them of the contents of Mr Gair’s letter— But they are not yet known to Mr Gallatin— Mr Bayard proposed to me to send Mr Gallatin Mr Speyer’s letter to me— I consented, if he would take it as the bearer; which he declined. He then thought it would be best to wait some days—perhaps there might be official dispatches communicating the fact with some softening to take off its unpleasantness.— Mr Bayard came again and passed an hour with us in the Evening. He was then anxious to have Mr Gallatin informed of the fact; thinking he might take it as no kindness to have it withheld from him— I advised Mr Bayard, if a favourable opportunity should occur, to mention it in a manner which would indicate kindness, to let him know it—thinking myself that a studious concealment of it for any length of time would scarcely be consistent with candour. We had also an Evening visit from the Duke and Duchess of Serra-Capriola, and their daughter.

20. After taking Charles to school this morning, I called upon Mr: Meyer to enquire if the seeds for Mr Wolcott had arrived from Moscow, and to endeavour to make some arrangement about my funds in his hands— The seeds are on the road—concerning the other object Mr Meyer will make enquiries— As I was returning home I met Dr Lowten, who told me that Captain Jones was ill with a pleurisy.— The remainder of the day I was confined at home by the weather— Read some pages in Goguet’s second Volume, and the first Canto of Child Harolde’s pilgrimage by Lord Byron; which Dr Beresford brought me yesterday— The plan of the Poem is original—the versification spirited—the character of Child Harolde purposely bad— The sentiments indicate the author’s youth— The best thing in the first Canto, is the description of the Spanish Bull-baiting.

21. I went this morning to the shops to make the necessary preparations for placing Charles at Mr Fishwick’s school during the winter. In the Evening I went with Mrs Adams, and paid visits to Mr and Madam Bardaxi, who were not at home, and at Countess Colombi’s— I had intended to make some other visits, but on returning home found Mr. Bayard was here— He told me that Mr Gallatin had this morning been informed by Mr Todd, of the Event of the nominations for the Extraordinary Mission— That he appeared to be little affected by it; but thought the Government, or his friends ought to have given him notice of the fact, that he might have had a better Season for leaving this Country— That he attributes the loss of the nomination to Mr King—supposes that the votes were 18 to 17. that there was one member absent, namely General Varnum; and that he was purposely absent to avoid leaving the decision to Mr Gerry, the Vice-President; knowing that he would have decided against the nomination— That he intends to take his passage directly for the United States, without waiting for official notice of the Event.— I received this morning a Notification from the Grand-Master of the Ceremonies Narishkin of a Court-mourning of six weeks for the Queen dowager of Sweden.

22. Rose this morning at a quarter past four, an hour earlier than my intended time, and in consequence of it lost two hours in the Evening. I called in the forenoon upon Mr Gallatin, whom I found quite unwell— He had sent his Son yesterday to enquire if I had any letters from Sweden by the Mail, but the mail did not arrive. When young Gallatin came I was out, and did not see him— I found Captain Jones with Mr Gallatin— He told me he had been very ill, and confined two or three days to his bed with a pleurisy.— The remainder of the day, I passed at home; reading Goguet, Plutarch, Ovid’s Fasti, and Child Harold, whose bitterness of invective upon Lord Elgin, for his dilapidations at Athens is so excessive that it borders upon the ridiculous.

23. This day four years have passed away since we arrived at St: Petersburg— I had a morning visit from Mr Montréal, and Evening visits from Mr: Lewis and Count Maistre— The Count brought me Petavius de Doctrina Temporum, which he borrowed for me from a public library.— I am so much afflicted with a Cold that I could read only a few pages this Evening.

24. Read prayers for the 19th. Sunday after Trinity. A Snow-Storm confined me to the house, excepting a short walk before dinner. The remainder of the day, I employed in reading—a few pages of Goguet—a few Stanzas of Childe Harold; but especially in father Petau’s doctrina Temporum— This is a work which I can do no more than skim over, for it would take me nine Months of hard and close Study to read it through with attention; and although I may perhaps not employ my Time better, I have not the courage to undertake it— I have however found in it, what I have long been wanting, that is some account of the Gregorian reformation of the Calendar— I now perceive also distinctly why the Easter of the Greek Church is celebrated the present year, not the first, but the second Sunday after the full Moon immediately succeeding the Vernal Equinox— It is because the full Moon in their Calendar falls four days later than the real full Moon of the firmament— The real full moon was on Thursday 15 April, and Easter-day consequently Sunday 18 April— But their full Moon, by the Julian Calendar was Monday 19 April, and they kept Easter on the next Sunday, the 25th.— The addition of the ten days in the Gregorian Calendar, is universally known, especially here where the Old Style is still adhered to, and where the new is still in very common use— But the correction of the lunar cycle by the same reform is so little understood that it had altogether escaped my attention; and when I enquired here from Ecclesiastics of various denominations, why the Easter of the Greek Church was kept a week too late, I found them as ignorant of the cause as myself— My cold is yet troublesome

25. Received a letter from Mr Speyer, enclosing one for Mr Bayard, and a packet of National Intelligencers to 5 August—that of the 3d: of that month contains the whole proceedings on the Appointments for the Extraordinary Mission to Russia; from the nominations untill the final votes of the Senate upon them— The votes for Mr Gallatin were 17 against 18—for Mr Bayard 28 against 6—for myself 30 against 4.— The vote that it was inexpedient to send a Minister Plenipotentiary to Sweden was 22 to 14.— Mr Gallatin’s son came in almost immediately after I received these papers, to ask if I had any letters— I sent them by him to Mr Bayard— We had snow the greatest part of the day, and this Evening—3 degrees by Reaumur’s Thermometer. I finished a long extract from Petau’s Doctrina Temporum.— Mrs Smith was quite unwell— I wrote to my Mother.

26. The thermometer this morning was at 4 1/2 degrees below 0; and in accompanying Charles to School, we found it necessary to a light and walk—the horses not being rough shod would not draw the Carriage— At the Bridge I found the workmen preparing to cut it away— Mr Harris and Mr Todd paid me morning visits; and Mr Milligan, Mr Todd and Mr Lewis were here at tea and part of the Evening— I was still unwell— Mr Harris told me Mr Gallatin intended to send to Count Romanzoff the National Intelligencer containing the proceedings of the U.S. Senate, on the nominations for the Russian Mission. He also said that he had seen Count Romanzoff last Sunday Morning; and that he appeared already acquainted with what the Senate had done— The two Gentlemen gave Captain Jones sailing orders yesterday Morning—to go and wait at Gothenburg for further orders— He went down to Cronstadt, intending if the wind should permit to sail this day.— This is the Empress-Mother’s birth-day; and she keeps it at Pavlofsky.

27. I was up in the middle of the Night, and therefore rose this morning later than usual—about 7. I placed Charles this morning at school at Mr Fishwick’s untill Christmas— Called at Mr Meyer’s to enquire about the seeds coming from Moscow, but he has heard nothing of them.— I attended the sale of books commenced this day at Grabit’s.— Read a little of Goguet, and a few of Lord Byron’s short Poems.

28. Received this Morning from Mr Gallatin, who sent it by Mr Smith, a Note from Count Romanzoff to the three Envoys, notifying them that the Empress Mother had fixed on next Sunday, at half past one O’Clock to receive them, and immediately after them the persons attached to the mission— I attended again at the sale of Books— Mr Bayard sent us the American Newspapers which he received on Monday. He and Mr Gallatin were here in the Evening at tea. He asked me whether I was aware of any objection to Mr Gallatin’s being presented with us to the Empress Mother— I said, none— He said the reason of his asking the question was that he understood Mr Harris, that I had asked the Question whether he intended to be presented; and did not know but there might be some objection of etiquette— I said I had no recollection of having asked the question, and certainly knew of no objection— The Chancellor’s note was explicit, that the Empress had appointed to receive us all three— This was all said in the hearing of Mr Gallatin who took no part in the Conversation— Mr Bayard spoke several times to Mrs Adams in a manner that I could not hear him— As soon as they were gone she informed me of what he had told her— It was the tidings of the decease of my dear and only Sister, Smith.— Mr Bayard said that he had seen it announced in an English Newspaper, a fortnight since— He afterwards sent the letter he received last Monday from Mr Fosdick at Gothenburg—
Mr Fosdick writes that he had seen it in a New-York Newspaper of 14. August— She died at my father’s at Quincy; it must have been between the 5th: and 10th: of August. I had been in some measure prepared for this severe affliction by my last Letters from my Mother. She was then, 14 July, expecting my Sister at Quincy, and anticipated the Event— Yet I was not aware that it would so soon ensue— May a gracious and merciful God, compensate in a happier world to this excellent woman, the heavy afflictions with which she has been visited on Earth. Her lot has been hard; but she has fulfilled to the utmost all the duties of social life— As a daughter, sister, wife and Mother her conduct has been without blemish and without reproach— She went through many vicissitudes of Fortune, and supported them all with the temperance and the fortitude of a Christian— Her bodily sufferings for the last three years have been of the sharpest and most distressing that human Nature is ever called to endure. She has born them with unbroken Spirit, untill nature sunk under the conflict— And Oh! may divine Providence give strength and energy to her Parents and mine to meet this new dispensation, and afford them consolation under it— Her son William had taken suspicion, or heard more of what Mr Bayard had said to Mrs Adams than I had; and she told him what it was— May it be profitable for good to him, to his father, brother and sister!— May no lesson of the great teacher, Death, be lost upon any one of us. May we all learn, to be also ready!

29. I was under too much agitation of mind, to pursue steadily any of my customary occupations— I read over part of the American Newspapers sent me by Mr Bayard— Attended a few minutes at the sale of Books, and walked through the Summer Gardens, which are in all the desolation of Winter. In the Evening I read some pages of Goguet, some poems of Lord Byron, and part of the second Book of Ovid’s Fasti. Mr Todd and Mr Lewis called here this Evening, but were not received.

30. Mr Appleton came to inform me that he intends going to-morrow to Cronstadt to embark for Sweden, and to proceed from thence to America; and he offered to take letters for me— I went to the lodgings of Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard; while I was there Mr. Todd came in, with further reports, contained in English Newspapers of an action between the American and British fleets on Lake Ontario, in which the British were defeated— I had received this account in a letter from Mr Speyer last Monday; but as it rested upon very remote and indirect authority, and there was then no other account of it received here, I had not indulged myself to give it credit. I may now hope it is not entirely without foundation. Mr Todd’s further news was that Count Wittgenstein had won a decisive victory near Dresden, for which there would be a Te Deum to-morrow— And that Lord Walpole had arrived last Evening and would be presented to the Empresses to-morrow.— I went to Mr Fishwick’s for Charles and brought him home with me— We were more impatient to see him than he was to come home— He had been four days absent, and it was the first time he had been a Night from home— The remainder of the day and Evening I was reading Petau’s Doctrina Temporum, Ovid’s Fasti, and Goguet.

31. Just after one O’Clock, I went to the lodgings of Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard, and accompanied them, together with Mr Harris, Mr Milligan, Mr Todd, and the young Gallatin to the palace; where we were presented, first to the Empress Mother—then to the Grand Dukes Nicholas and Michaël, and lastly to the Grand Duchess Ann— There had been some question whether according to the Etiquette we should be presented in mourning—to solve which, Mr Harris had written to the Grand Master of the Ceremonies, and had received for answer from Mr Swistounoff that we should— We accordingly wore crapes round the arm, at the sword-hilt, and in the hat. Mr Swistounoff also mentioned as points of etiquette the three bows on advancing to the presence of the imperial personages, and the three on retiring from it, with the precaution of stepping backwards without turning round— The Empress Mother however on our entering her apartment immediately advanced towards us, and scarcely gave time for the three bows— She expressed very courteously her satisfaction at my new appointment, and her hope that it would prolong my stay at her Son’s Court; and she was equally polite in her addresses to Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard— Spoke of America, of the long voyage, of this City, the river, the Climate &c— On her enquiring whether my Colleagues had visited the places in the vicinity of the City, Mr Gallatin mentioned that they had seen with great admiration the beneficent Institutions under her patronage— This was a favourite topic for her, and she conversed upon it, several minutes. She said that she did not approve the principle of the foundling hospitals, because she thought it was encouraging immorality; but as they had been instituted by the Empress Catherine, it was just to respect her intentions, and carry them as far as possible into effect. The late Emperor had always had it much at heart, and her Son had never ceased to take great interest in it. She mentioned it as a great evidence of the morality of the Russian People, that when in consequence of the last years disasters, when the Enemy penetrated to the very capital of the Empire, and the
children under the care of these Institutions had been dispersed all over the Country, yet the people into whose hands they had fallen had generally taken so good care of them, that out of seven thousand, to which their numbers amounted there were only eighteen of whom there was yet no account what had become of them— And the mortality among the rest had scarcely been greater than in ordinary years.— She spoke also of our benevolent Institutions in America; and particularly those relating to the management of Prisons— She had read with great pleasure the accounts of them, and she admired the idea of aiming at the reformation rather than the punishment of offenders— She said she had heard there was a great similarity between the Russian and the American People for which reason she rejoyced the more in the good qualities of her Countrymen— The Grand-Dukes, and the Grand-Duchess Ann, spoke only of the common topics of weather, climate, the City and the Country— Our Audiences, were all over and I returned home in the space of an hour.— I read prayers for the 20th: Sunday after Trinity.— Walking before dinner I met Mr Appleton, on the Quay— He goes to-morrow Morning— I had sent a packet of letters for America to his lodgings— He told me he had received from Mr Lewis a further account of the Action upon Lake Ontario— It is less favourable then the first account I had from Mr Speyer.— In the evening I read Goguet.

Day. I have risen irregularly this month between 4 and 7.— Almost habitually by candle-light. Read and write untill half past eight—then ride with Charles to school; and walk home— Having now placed Charles at Board with Mr Fishwick, this morning walk will henceforth cease— I Breakfast about ten, and spend the remainder of the day as in the preceding Months. I now bestow all my leisure upon Chronological enquiries— Like every other object of study they spread and widen before me as I advance— Hills peep o’er hills, and Alps on Alps arise. Hence my progress is excessively slow; and I am continually beset with temptations to stray from one study to another. My health, and of course my capacity of application has been better this month than the last— Yet I have not effected more. I pray for Patience and Perseverance.
